text:
CAN. A clean orange to gold, zero dead.. Yep, can is 
Spot on, citrus peel & coriander/spices.. Yeastie body with hits of coriander, peppercorns & big orange notes, a touch of booze?.. Sourced REAL a gastropub Waikiki
Can at Kantishna. Hazy caramel color. Smells of spice and banana. Spiced flavor, A tad flat.
From the can at the bar of the Denali Back Country Lodge poured a brownish/gold brew with a white head. Full bodied and malty like youd expect from a triple. I liked it.

Shared bomber poured to snifters displaying a hazed, orangey gold color, with a presentable layer of off white head foam, and clingy dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was light spice as coriander, light yeastiness with subtle hints of banana & vanilla, and citrusy esters highlighting mandarin orange & zest. The taste followed similarly, contributing low bitterness and complementary booze. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation. Appreciate the tweaking & metamorphosis. Quite tasty! Thanks Mark for the contribution to the session!

A clear deep amber color with a short lived off-white head. Dried orange peel, Allspice, bubblegum, light yeast, dusty. Sweet up front, wow, really too sweet. Treacle, bubblegum, slick feel, has a hint of bitterness in the follow, seems a tad thin, its a good beer, a bit too sweet for me and lacks the layers of complexity found in the top echelon of Belgian Ales.
Not a fan of this style but loved this. Orange and hazy. Spicy and fruity. Not super boozy. Thick syrupy feel. Can from Justin. Oh yeah great can art.
Draft, slightly cloudy amber, some white head. Aroma malt and citrus. Taste malt, sweet lemon and orange. Palate quite rich, carb good

Aroma: caramel, fruity, yeast, spices, straw. Appearance: hazy amber, light, off-white head. Taste: heavy sweet. Palate: sweets continue, fruity, spices again, sweet malts, caramel. Overall: very nice Tripel, good spices in the palate. Pint at brewery, Anchorage.

Pours a fairly clean and soft golden amber with one finger of off white head. Nose is not so good. Tons of apple juice (all apple juice) with some raw bread dough/yeast and stone fruit. Flavor is gross, real gross. Apple juice and raw bread dough. Eww. Medium full body.

The alcohol may catch some off guard but my wifes clothes arent falling off without an auxiliary shot of tequila. Quite complex, with coriander and other spices, yeast, citrus and other fruits, and more. Not a traditional tripel but thats no bad thing.

Pours dark for style, an amber orange (not the usual yellow-orange). Aroma is orange, bubblegum, spice. Taste is sweeter than expected, but well balanced with spice, pepper, coriander, orange peel, apple cinnamon, apricot. Quite nice overall. Very drinkable for the abv; would sessionable even, if it were cheaper.
Tap. Dark golden pour with a lot of head. Honey, coriander, orange peel, pepper. Sweet and fruity. Hides alcohol well and makes it a dessert drink even for a non-beer drinker

Poured from big bottle. Aroma is citrus, spice, syrup and white bread. Cloudy dark gold with minimal head. I taste brown sugar, orange peel, citrus, coriander, pepper, cinnamon, yeast, malt. Lots of different flavors which work quite well together. Good drinkability, and alcohol is not noticed. Nicely done, enjoyable beer.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: "i dug this one, though 11.99 was a bit extreme. spiced like a wit but with the spiciness and already-there fruitiness of a nice tripel. holds up well. very fruity and very tasty. nice change."
Bottle. Nose of spicy citrus, honey, bread, coriander, oranges. Deep golden color with lace, cloudy. Very sweet, estery flavors, peaches, apricot. Ok, but very sweet and not all that special.

New Beer Distributors, NYC 650ml ($8.75): Pours orange with a not very large head. Aroma is orange, spice, bubblegum, and no alcohol to speak of. Taste is sweet. Alcohol is well covered. Plenty of citrus. Mouthfeel is nice. Light aftertaste. I can see why it got its nickname.

Yeasty, bready aroma with undertones of banana and bubblegum. Beautiful golden color with very active white head. Bubblegum washes over the tounge bouyed by banana bread. Hints of citrus on the sides of tounge. No hint of alcohol burn
Poured from bottle. Clear, orange color. Good head but disapated quickly. Excellent carbonation. Sweet aroma of fruit. Crisp start, tart but with a sweet finish. Enjoyed it very much. A new favorite.
Sweet apricot aroma. Pours clear orange with a thin white head. Really flavorful, lots of sweetness with a long fruity finish.
Draft. Pours golden orange with a white head. Fruity and spicy, with peach, vanilla, hints of booze, and a light spicy yeasty finish. Nice enough.

Surprisingly quaffable, very complex and interesting twist on a Belgian tripple . Coriander and orange notes provide bittering to balance residual sweetness and alcohol. Wife loves it, the name is accurate.

(Draught) clear, tepid gold liquid, almost no bubbles and looks syrupy in the glass. Nose of mango, perm chemicals, tons of coriander and orange peel, sticky sweet smell. Taste has more coriander than any beer I can recall, peppery, floral, touches of tropical flavors and orange peel, orange marmalade. Sweet and medium thick body, needs more attenuation and carbonation In my opinion.
Deep amber with a cream head. Nose is orange, spice, musk, yeast, dried fruits. Smooth palate, light alcohol, dried fruits, orange, citrus, heavy spice.

On tap at Beer Culture NYC. Orange hazy pour with a slight head. Aroma is slight citrus. Taste is lemon vs orange. Orange wins. Very smooth. You could get drunk off this easy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to Terry Stovall for bringing this back from Anchorage AK --- Cloudy medium amber with a head cover, lace that slides back into the drink. Taste is tart wheaty malt that is joined by more bittering than 15 ibus suggest, giving way to coriander and orange in the finish. This is a real original that works on its own terms, but is not a solid representative of the style. Worth seeking out.

August 17th, 2012 - Midnight Sun Brewing Companys lasciviously named Panty Peeler might be the "beer of trip" up to Alaska. We picked it up in a small liquor store somewhere in Sitka, mostly on a lark. As tourists are "curio lust" was in full swing - our instincts demanded we by some kind of tasteless crap to commemorate the adventure to the tamest part of the untamed Alaskan wilderness. For me, the Panty Peeler fit the bill perfectly. The label and name were worth a boyish chortle and a guffaw, and it promised to be more enjoyable than a t-shirt covered in crude innuendo and half-hearted sexual puns. But the real treat was that the beer inside wasnt merely satisfactory, or even good. It was EXCELLENT. The nose has a twangy, funky fresh banana note, coupled with e Brettanomyces twang that resonates like a loud, plucked banjo string in a silent room. Clove creeps into the nose as well, though it trips itself up as it immerses deeper into the yeasty funk of this brews bouquet. On the tongue this beer is predominantly sudsy, and maybe even excessively so, but eventually the flavor musters the courage to step forward and express itself. When it does, theres lots of light orange and lemon flavors, decorated with a cherry sweetness, and the light tart tang of meringue. The body is light (reasonably so), demonstrating a good balance between mouthfeel and flavors. With a little time and patience, the carbonation is tempered, revealing a delicately balanced brew that once again shows off Alaskan proficiency in lighter brews.

Pours a hazy, barely transparent dark apricot. Strong, fruity aroma has a good yeasty underpinning. Bold, mainly fruity flavor has notes of pear, apricot and banana. Texture is firm and strongly fizzy, and leaves a fruity finish. Peel yer panties for this one!

HMOG 2014. Thought someone said this had several years on it. Aged very nicely then. Light hazed orange pour. Sweet white grape, juicy, hints of fruity easters, citrus. Bits of booze splashy. Very nice triple.
The aroma is fruit, apple, spicy. The appearance is hazy yellow, white head. The flavor is peppery, fruity. The finish is pepper, sweet, light fruit. Medium in body. Nice.
Pours deep golden. Aroma is ohenolic, fruity, fruity alcohols, peaches. Flavor peaches, clean sweet malts and a moderately dry finish. Really nice.
22 ounce bottle. Pours a golden red with a small beige head. Aroma of fruit, malt, yeast, and spice. Taste is yeast, orange, malt, coriander, and caramel. A touch sweet. Very good.

Pours a beautiful hazed orange color with a cantalope melon hue. Just wonderful to look at. Not a whole lot of lace from my lazy pour and it fell fast to a thin ring. Nose is vivacious and has plenty of exotic tropical fruit. Sweet and juicy. Theres a touch of malt that hints at bread and offers just a light sweetness on the nose. No alcohol on the nose, but a nice bit of earthy coriander. The scent of orange is deep within the beer and is an all around orange fruitiness. 

Taste is wonderful. This beer offers a tremendous fruit sweetness with lush and heady tropical fruits and an all around orange flavor too. The malt suggests bread but does not become too heavy or too bready. Wonderful mouthfeel on this that is due to that malt. The coriander is earthy and lends a depth. There is a nice yeast dryness that takes the mid palate just as you are begining to swoon from all that wild tropical flavor. Then it finishes with a sweet and warming alcohol that has a spice and pepper of its own. A lingering fruity aftertaste.

This beer is a delight!

Draft at the growler NYC. Pours a golden bronze color with no head. Taste and smells of slight booze . Very good triple 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Orange golden pour with white head. Light yeast, spice and Belgian tones in aroma and flavor, kind of mild for 9%...

13 dec 2013, bottle. Yellow, clear, no bubbles. Nose is straw and amber malt. Thin body, slightly syrupy, mildly fizzy. Gold syrup and granila malt ok. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy golden yellow/orange/amber colored body with a half finger white head that quickly dies leaving some super light lacing, the aroma has a little bit of orange peel, some coriander that adds a bit of spiciness, a little bit of lemon all backed up with some light Belgian yeast, the flavor is sweet yet spicy and somewhat malty, orange/coriander aftertaste, dry spicy finish, its somewhat easy on the palate, overall, good somewhat sessionable tripel, probably better in the summer months, but makes for a good night

Hazy golden, moderate head, decent lace/retention. Aroma is slightly sour malt with notes of orange, coriander, yeast. Medium bodied, lightly sweet, light sourness, alcohol hidden well. Comes off as American but its kind of an interesting take on the style. Better than most US examples, but pales compared to my favorites.

Very nice tripel. Belgian yeast notes play a solid background and resonate throughout boldly. Citrus notes add interest. Quite lightly carbonated, and heavier in mouthfeel than typical of the style. B+

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap: cloudy orange pourwith large white head. Aroma is yeasty, perfumy, caramel, dried orange peel and honey. Flavor is tangy, spicy with belgian yeast funk, some tart grass, bitter-tart lemon and orange peel, and a little honey sweetness. I liked it overall, it has a spicy palate with a mild bitter and sweetness throughout. Not an oh wow beer but definitely good.

Orange pour with a white head. The aroma is full of orange, coriander, Belgian yeast and biscuit malt. The flavor is full of juicy oranges with coriander and biscuit malt. Tastes like very pulpy orange juice. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
2011 Bottle from mora2000. .Pour is golden with a thin wuite uead..Nose is spice, citrus, bread, fruit.Taste is heavy pulp, orange, spice, pineapple..

22oz aged bottle, shared by phaleslu at Natifest 2013. Hazy orange / amber color. Little bubbly white head. Couple splotches of lace. Interesting tropical flavor. Huge pineapple juice flavor, straight up. Lightly soft, crisp carbonation. Dry finish. Bigger body. Lightly tart, moderate bitter taste. Very odd for a tripel. Minimal belgian yeast character. I like it, though.

22 oz. bottle from a long-ago trade. Cant remember who sent it because I was trading so much a few years ago. Anyway, this one pours golden with a small eggshell colored head. Aroma of toffee, vanilla, dried fruits (particularly golden raisins and apricots), and sweet, bready malts. Flavor of pineapple, apricot, raisin, caramel, and syrup. Medium-bodied, with a mouthfeel that starts juicy and becomes more malty. Moderate carbonation. Nice tripel. This one worked well for me.
Aged bottle shared at natifest. Pours a lighter copper with not much head. Aroma has some banana and spices. Tastes like bananas and creme. Some pineapple comes through, too. Impressive.
sampled at NatiFest 2013 - pale amber with offwhite head. nope! flavor adds cheese, caramel and citrus. sweet.
Bottle shared at Natifest. Fruity, nice aroma, sweet malts. Nice smooth palate. East down. Great flavor.
On tap at Wholefoods. Pours a pale brown color with out much of a head. Not too sweet and slight hoppy bitterness. Wonderful belgian yeast flavors.

The smell is pleasant. The head tastes of apples and the first taste of the beer itself is immediately crisp and apple-filled. The body of the flavor recalls alcoholic ciders, with a touch of bitterness. Not too much aftertaste, but overall a great beer.

Bouteille de 22 oz partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Légère odeur dagrume et dépice. Apparence: La couleur est dorée. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dorange avec une pointe de coriandre et de miel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #4928)
Hazy orange gold with fruity honey-like aroma. Dry with complex citrus and white grape flavors.

Golden orange in color... Aroma of citrus fruits... Flavor is sweet citrus fruits, candi sugar and notes of Belgian yeast... Great tripel, very impressive...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
22oz bottle pours a copper orange with an off white head. Fruit zest aroma. Taste of orange zest honey and grapes

22 oz. bottle- Pours hazy orange with a one finger head that reduces. Aroma is orange, syrupy, coriander. The taste is Belgian yeast, orange, floral, dandelion, too malty sweet, different than any tripel I have ever had. Body is medium and sticky, carbonation is medium. Good, but have had better, kudos for trying something new, but cant match the goodness of an authentic Belgian tripel.

Bomber Bottle: Pours a clear orange copperish color with a medium off-white head that is mostly lasting. Mild fruity aroma has hints of grapes, pears, coriander, and orange peel. Malty flavor starts sweet and fruity with hints of orange peel and honey, then  finishes with a spicy, peppery mouthfeel. Nice balance of the fruit and spice notes. Delicious!

22 ounce bottle into chalice, no bottle dating.  Slight gusher upon opening, but not bad.  Pours a lightly cloudy deep orange amber color with a 1 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lasts.  Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation.  Aromas of peach, pear, orange peel, apple, clove, coriander, pepper, bread, honey, herbal, and earthy yeast spiciness.  Very nice aromas with good balance, strength, and complexity of fruity and spicy esters; quite a bit more peppery than I expected.  Taste of pear, apple, orange peel, peach, coriander, clove, bread, honey, pepper, herbal, and earthy yeast spiciness.  Lingering notes of citrus, light fruits, coriander, clove, bread, honey, pepper, herbal, and earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice balance and complexity of fruity/spicy flavors; with a great balance between sweetness/spiciness; and zero cloying sweetness present after the finish.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a fairly slick and lightly crisp mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a damn nice tripel!  Great balance of fruity/spicy flavors with good complexity; and very smooth to sip on.  A very enjoyable offering.
On draught a Saraveza 2/23/13.  Sweet grape aroma.  Grape and golden berry flavors. Finishes with a hint of bitterness mixed with the sweet.

Pour is a hazy copper with a small tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt and a little orange peel.  Flavor is caramel, sweetness and dark bread. Finish has more sugary sweetness and not much else.  This was just ok, way too sweet and not enough Belgain yeastness and no where near a triple in my book.  This was more of a sweet biere de garde.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, nice hazy orange-yellow pour with nice white head, aroma brought notes of orange peel, pear, grape notes, hints of a slight salty note, hints of bready and yeasty notes, hints of earth, slight grass in there, nice spice with coriander as well.  Taste is a nice mix of grass, grain, biscuit, leading into a slight salty note, hints of citrus peel, coriander and more spice notes with yeast and slight belgian esters, hints of slight peach and pear notes, finishing fairly spicy, more orange peel, and more coriander. Dries out a bit heavily on the end as well, almost a slight oaky note.  This is pretty tasty, though a bit heavy on the accented flavors.
Nice golden pour with small head. Light spice with orange on the back end. Overall, a refreshing drink.

Bottle at my parents, shared with my dad. Appearance is hazy orange with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Bread, orange peel, clove, a touch of basil, coriander, and bubblegum in the aroma. Taste is big clove and spice, a touch of banana, basil, bready, cereal, and herbs with a slight spicy finish. Medium body with soft carbonation. Pretty decent tripel, but not top notch; maybe its a touch old.

Perhaps the most crisp tripel I have ever had.  Pours a golden orange color with a white soapy head.   Has an aroma of caramel and orange zest, some grapefruit mixed in.  Has a sweet caramel, orange zest taste with some earthiness.   Light and crisp.  Medium body.  Tasty.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Created a firm development of white head while the liquid was a golden blonde color. As for the nose, a big spicy Belgian yeast dominates with a buttery aroma that also allows for some earthy hops. The flavor is heavy and holds a thick base of sticky malts while also boasting spicy Belgian yeast that arrives on cue which mirrors the aroma with a direct replication. This is a heavy hitting Belgian triple that will seal the deal in my book as a worthy contender when American triples are brought up and mentioned.

Bottle at Beer Universe Saugerties:  Hazy amber in the mug with a thin oily head that sits and looks at you.  Sparse droopy lacing.  They talk alot about the orange peel and the coriander but it seems about average at first but become more robust as it warms.   Rising body to yeast and spice finish.  I am certain this critter has peeled a few in its day.  Tripels always seem so daunting since they will smack you down quickly. This critter is surprisingly drinkable.  Nose of spice.  Quick compact and powerful body.  Finish strikes just as I was enjoying the body and makes the brew a bit of a let down. Not enough contemplation time. A longer body would give me a better ride.
Bottle, this was a drain pour for me, it was very harsh with not backbone to hide the harshness and it was tough to drink. I will give it another chance if I see it again

Dark orange tinted gold. Clear all the way through. The orange peel is liqueur-like on the nose. Very powerful, accented with yeasty esters. Full bodied Tripel with a balanced mix of spice, yeast and fruit. Very long finish with a hint of alcohol heat. Very good.

(Bottle) Pours deep orange. The aroma holds doughy/spicy/white peppery yeast, crackers, bread, dry marzipan, citrus peel, banana, pears, melon, touch of red berries, cinnamon, nutmeg, coriander and a dash of grassy/herbal hops. Complex and balanced nose. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and tiny acidic with notes of spices, fruits, bread/cracker-like malt, mild but green hops and a dash of phenols. The mouthfeel is clean with a light to medium carbonation. Spicy, bready, doughy and light phenolic. Near medium bodied.

Bomber courtesy of Marsiblursi. Pours clear amber with a small frothy goldenish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sweet and spicy with biscuits, green grapes, allspice, cloves, crackers, white pepper, coriander, candi sugar, hay, plums, dry soil, banana, honey, pears, tobacco and hints of alcohol. Taste is slightly sweet, tiny bitter and spicy with banana, green apples, overripe pears, nutmeg, allspice, white pepper, hay, raspberry ha candy, moist soil, watermelon, candi sugar and hints of bread and sheet metal. Mouthfeel is slightly smooth, round and medium bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and tiny bitter with candi sugar, white pepper, allspice, dry soil, hay, thai basil, cloves, banana bread and green grapes.

Bottle at Mumsig Miniprovning, Göteborg. Amber beer with a small and quickly disappearing offwhite head. Fruity yeasty aroma, apples, pear, barnyard notes, pepper, citrus, banana, cinnamon, nutmeg, candy notes. Fruity yeasty flavor, spicy, peppery, red berries, pear, salt notes, herbal, some warming alcohol, coriander, apples, very nice balance. Pear finish, yeasty, spicy from white pepper and coriander. Well done!

Bottle @ MMP. Pours clear amber with a small off white head leaving some lacing. Aroma is sweet fruity malty yesty coriander slightly orange citric. Flavor is sweet malty yeasty tea a bit bitter spicy pungent pears bananas fruity. Finishes bitter pungent sweet fruity.
65cl, American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, spicy/sweet and slightly bitter/fruity, balanced, hazy, small head, nice brew, yet expensive!

Copper with minimal head.  Candy sugar toffee mildly spicy aroma.  Very sweet candy sugar and peach syrup with herbal slightly citric long woody finish.   Cloying, thick, underattenuated.  Typical American tripel rendition, syrupy sweet, heavy handed.  Still okay.

Hazy orange body, white head. Aroma of wet malt, bit alcohol, strong sweetness. Flavour is bit spicy yeast with sweet malt and alcohol. Some orange. Unbalanced, much alcohol and nothing to do with trippel.
Tap at Stagshead.  Pours hazy copper with thin head and decent lacing.  Nose of tropical fruits.  Tastes of banana, tangerines, cloves, pepper, honey, vanilla, floral and grass.

Bottle: Poured a copper color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is soft fresh orange and coriander. Taste is slightly spicy with orange peel, coriander, and sticky malt. Very lively on the tongue through!

29th December 2009ChrisO Night Of The Gaylords tasting. Hazy amber beer. Very soft palate, semi dry. Light caramel and toffee malt. Light as a feather! Mild minerals and a dash of hop. Very light and airy beer. Pretty good.

Hazy orange-copper with fair, creamy, white head / Sweet, unctuous nose of banana, orange, clove, and coriander / Full body, very sweet, malty, with poor hop balance / Borderline cloying flavors of banana, orange, pineapple, clove, and coriander / Lacks subtlety, but not body or flavor.

Bottle. Pours a muddy amber with a thick white head that leaves a lot of lacing. Spicy-sweet aroma, of oranges, preserved citrus peel, coriander, yeast, sugar, malt. Taste is crisp and rich, of baking spices, orange zest, lemon, yeast, grass, sugar. Lingering coriander and orange crispness. Very tasty.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Served in a Midnight Sun goblet.

Pours a clear deep golden color with a single-finger white head that dissipates fairly quickly into a thin collar. Plenty of bubbles visible in the glass. Given the look on this and Fallen Angel, Im thinking there must be nucleation spots on the bottom of this glass. Still, very nice looking.

The nose carries a bit of earthy mustiness along with a touch of citrus and spice. Nothing too exciting. Really muted. The flavor has some mild phenols plus a touch of citrus and some backing grain. Nothing too interesting, unfortunately.

Body is light-medium with a hefty dose of carbonation and a dry finish. Theres a touch of chewiness. Mild alcohol as well.

There wasnt anything particularly wrong with this one, I just couldnt find anything about it to really like.

Thin off-white head which dissipates rather quickly.  Strong malty and hoppy aroma with lots of orange and corriander that whallops you right in the nose.  Some spicy yeast notes too.Clear dark copper in color.  Strong malt backbone with lots of fruity flavors and sickly sweet malts.  Exceptionally dry late swallow, almost to the point that it creates a lump in your throat.  Noticable alcohol presence and warming.  Pasty finish that is strong malts and a bit of butterscotch.  An ok tripel that really is americanized.

22oz bomber, at a eatery in Seward, Ak. Pours a cloudy apricot color with a thin white head. Lacing remains on the glass after each sip. Yeasty aroma with a nice faint fruity scent. Bittersweet hop and fruit flavor. Crisp with enough carbonation to keep it light on the tongue.

A slightly cloudy golden yellow color with a white head.  A nice sweetness to it from the malt and sugar.  Plenty of citrus character and a bit of pineapple as well.  A touch of yeast as well as a mild spiciness.  The flavor is quite nice.  Sweet fruit: both citrus and tropical fruits.  Just a light spiciness and some yeast flavor to it as well.  Pretty solid beer.

Chestnut pour with a small eggshell head...crimson, ruby, and scarlett hues. Aroma of Belgian yeast, banana, caramel, honey, touch of clove. Similar flavors with a bit of citrus to break up the sweetness.  Also get some dark fruit and nuts.  Cant taste the alcohol...well hidden.  Not bad!

22oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep ruby/copper with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of strong caramel malts, some spicy yeast, and a decent amount of hops.  A good amount and blend of everything.  Smooth texture. A pretty good beer.

very nice rich belgiany aroma with candy, brown sugar, banana, clove, grape juice, and malt. pours a clear light amber (dark for a tripel) with no head. slightly sweet but complex flavor with fruit and spice. very low carbonation but not too heavy. very nice overall though a bit hard to finish between sweetness and low carbonation.

22 ounce bottle that poured a rather light yellow color, aromas of spice, banana, sweet sugar, and a touch of bitter hops.  Flavors are mild, I think some of the sugar cancels out some of the spice from the Belgium yeast, however it was still a nice beer over all.

Pours bright, transluscent gold with a large, bubbly white head.  The aroma is classic trippel... dominated by sweet sugars, suppored by caramel malt aromas, and balanced out by dryness from mildly bitter hops.  The flavor is a bit disappointing, however.  While the aroma was full and complex, the palate came through as much thinner than expected.  Sweet and balanced, but a bit too mild.  I think that the name led me to expect a massively sweet, sugary, fruity trippel, and perhaps thats not fair, but it is what it is.

The Panty Peeler.  I had this shipped across the country by a friend of mine, and Im glad I did.  This tripel is a great example of the style.  Clear golden pour with a white head that was pretty quick to leave.  A characteristicly "Belgian" sweetness, some mild bread and malt with a clear hint of alcohol.   This is a beer that could sneak up on you quickly if you arent careful.
On Tap at Beachwood BBQ. Med. color, citrus and spice taste that make this one of my best picks for a Belgian beer.

This is my first taste of an Alaskan beer - I must say I have been curious to taste what they are doing up yonder, and have been wondering what special qualities Alaskan beer might have.  PP doesnt really answer those questions, so I guess Ill have to drink on.  Light, sweet, bready aroma.  Standard amber/orange pour.  A fairly sweet and bready brew with a dry hop tingle in the finish.  There is an undertone of yeasty funk.  It is a little too sweet and yeasty to be a great tripel imho, but this is still a fine brew.
Draft at city beer, SF. CA. Orange golden pour. Bubble gum heavy flavor, very sweet, orange peel, too sweet IMO. Spicy coriander notes. Ok
Pours a golden shade of apple juice. Thin and quickly dissipating white lacing. Aromas of orange peel and coriander dominate hints of apple from the yeast.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 From the 2/2012 3R6P tasting. One of the better beers of this session. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a murky orange color with a small white head that left no lacing. The aroma was sweet bread, sugar, peach and apricot. The flavor was tangy and sweet with strong candied apricot, pear and faint pepper. The finish was long and sweet with lingering sugar, apricot and pear. Fairly full bodied. Excellent.

Bottle from secret santa.  Im drinking this with mtjoseph in hopes of getting him out of his panties tonight.  Shouldnt be a problem, but it doesnt hurt to have a little help.  Clear, golden orange in color with a small white head.  Looks really nice in the glass.  Fruity, sugary, and slightly yeasty in the aroma.  Aroma has candy sugar, oranges, and a slight spice character.  Nothing really stands out in the aroma, but it definitely is appealing still.  Slightly sweet and fruity in taste, but not at all cloying.  Lots of berry characters here, some sweet candy sugar.  Finish has some grains and berries.  Really nice finish.  Medium bodied.  Slightly sticky.  Really well done.

Bomber shared with mattyb83.  Pours a really nice bright golden color with just a tad of haze to the appearance.  A slightly creamy head also complements.  Aroma full of the orange peels and coriander with that traditional Belgian yeast characteristic present.  Almost smells like a saison a little bit.  Surprised how much I like this beer.  Really light bodied, yet packs a lot of bright Mandarin orange citrus with an equally balanced spice aspect with a little grain.  Alcohol is completely masked and is overall quite clean. Really enjoy this for being on the fruitier side of Tripel.

hazy dark golden/light amber, with a big white head that slowly fades and leaves nice fluffy lacing... aroma has notable citrus, orange, coriander, fairly spicy, fruity belgian yeast, it is definitely a cross between a white and a triple as far as the aroma goes.. mildly herbal aroma... lively body, kinda sweet finishes a bit dry, medium body, lightly slick then dries out in the finish... some definite notes of citrus and herbs, definitely more of an imperial white than a triple, some spice....

Pours an opaque amber color with a medium tan head...light sediment.  Aroma is spicy...coriander and a cinnamon note...bit of citrus too...fruity beligian yeasty notes.  Flavor has notable spice..clove and coriander...and some earthy, wheaty malt notes...dry earthy/spicy hop notes...tastes like a cross between a wit and a dubbel.  Mouthfeel is medium and super lively and the finish is somewhat dry with an earthy malt note.
clear golden amber pour with medium head. aroma of banana, clove, citrus fruits, and spice. flavor of orange, spice, clove, and some yeast

Bottle from Grape Expectations, Anchorage. Hazy medium orange-amber body, thick cream head. Nose mostly of pineapple; also pears, white grapes, and cloves. Dusty, herbal body featuring primarily cloves, bubblegum, and pineapple. Solid tripel.

[Tap] Tried this at the brewery in mid-September under the name Panty Peeler. Pours a dark golden color with a bit of haze to it. Has a dense white head. Aroma of orange and lemon peels, sweet fruity esters and some vanilla. Mild and fruity taste includes peaches, pear, bubblegum, vanilla and hints of lemongrass. Smooth mouthfeel with a lively amount of carbonation. Tasty and well balanced. Good stuff for sure.

Bottle @ home. Clear, red-one appearance with a fluffy, white head. Slightly toasty, sweet malty, belgian yeasty, coriander, orange peel aroma. Tangy, orange citrusy, belgian yeasty, light barnyard flavor. Tangy, belgian yeasty aftertaste. One of the better American Tripels.

Bomber bought a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($11.59).  Pours a reddish-amber hue with one finger of lazy white head that soon dissipates.  Aroma of bready malts, bright citrus peel, lemongrass, yeast, and some spice.  Flavor has some nice citrus notes, lightly sweet bread, light caramel malts, and some finishing spice.  Medium bodied with some lingering spiciness.  The high ABV is well concealed.  Nothing especially exciting here but its a very drinkable trippel.  (344, 617)
(tap) clear yellow colour with small white head; aromas of spice, citrus; balanced flavour, quite good

Bottle shared with blankboy, garthicus, mabel & jerc - courtesy of mabel & jerc. Consumed and notes taken on Jan 16, 2009. Hazy golden with a medium sized white head. Zingy aroma of coriander, orange zest, yeast and a bit of ginger. Medium bodied with a slightly creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is delicious, with the notes of orange and peach and spice and yeast combining into something sweet (but not TOO sweet) and zippy and just damn good.

Bottle. Pours a full golden with rocky white head. Aroma is sugary bubblegum and white pepper. Overly sweet bubblegum phenols with orange peel and a hint of yeast. Way too sweet. Off balanced and not all that enjoyable.

On tap @ brewery.  Hazy golden orange color with a wild aroma of candy (jolly ranchers?) and Belgian yeast.  Not at all my style, with too much twang and too much sugar, almost like a hard cider.  On to the next taster!

22oz bottle from marina market. pours a hazy, orange-gold with a thick, rocky white head with short retention and light rings of lace. aroma is damn nice but subtle with spicy yeast, orange peel, coriander, and light clove with subtel notes of biscuit, vanilla, and lemon grass. flavor is delicious with sweet belgian yeast, dry grass, and vanilla covered oranged backed by subtle spice notes of coriander, clove, and lemon peel with hints of toffee. palate is medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a dry, spiced, citrusy finish. overall, a damn nice tripel.
Bottle.  Clear pale yellow with a small white head.  Belgian candies, spices, and yeast aromas.  The taste follows suit with the addition of fruit esters.  A nice tripel, its just not my thing..

Split this with KevSal at City Beer Store in SF. Poured into a fluted glass. 

4.0 A: Hazed orange brown color. Two fingers of off-white, creamy/frothy hybrid head. Good retention and some lacing.

4.5 S: Wonderful! Coriander comes through big time with orange peel on its heels. Solid peppery spiciness. Very clean overall with a "clean" peachy fruitiness. Light yeastiness.

4.0 T: Coriander is a big player in the taste as well and so is the orange peel. Peppery spiciness. Peach and lightly citrus fruitiness. Lightly yeasty with sweeter than average for the style maltiness.

4.5 M: Medium body. Good spritzy carbonation. Super smooth with a good creaminess.

4.5 D: Stellar tripel. Right up there with the best from Belgium.

Serving type: bottle

Old "Panty Peeler" bottle thanks to savnac.  Pour is a rusty copper color with a pretty minimal white head.  Aroma is loaded with Grand Marnier orange aromas with notes of spice, light caramel malt, light honey syrup, and a light marshmallow sweetness.  Really very enticing despite the sweetness.  Flavor is less sweet than expected with notes of caramel malt, slightly burnt brown sugar, light spice, and an orange liquor finish.  I liked this more than I thought I would.  Not sure when this was brewed but I think its at least 2.5 years old and drinking like a champ right now. Thanks again Ira!

Sampled at Repeal of Prohibition fest 2011 - Pour clear golden with a beige head.  The aroma is very sweet with tropical fruits, toasty malt, caramel and Belgian yeast.  The aroma is very clean.  Medium / full body that has lots of carbonation.  The taste is like the aroma, but even sweeter along with spice and banana esters.  This was good, but a bit too sweet for my tastes these days.
Nice, light but pleasant nose....some citrus qualities.  Clear amber color with a thin head.  Some sweetness and full palate.  Lost my notes but would definitely recommend.
(draught - Schlafly Repeal of Prohibition) Copper. Spice aroma. Flavor of spice, yeast, orange, slightly sweet.

Bottled sample via Savvy1982, shared with him and oakbluff. Pale copper in colour with moderate carbonation. Very fruit driven on the nose, with elements of apple juice, peach, and apricot, along with some sticky pilsner malt. Flavours are of creme caramel, vanilla pod, cooked sugar, more sour peach, and sour cream. The first few sips leave a bit of savory spice on the palate, but a tongue coating lactic quality takes over immediately after that. Its definitely not a classic tripel, but still makes for an interesting beverage.

In short: A spicy triple with many problems
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed fresh a few weeks after purchase in Portland Oregon.  Tasting session with Montreal crew.
The look: Cloudy dark blonde body topped by a small white head
In long: Nose has some burnt plastic and fruity yeast esters (mainly bananas).  Not so nice aroma to be honest.  Taste is ripe bananas, excessive spiciness, yeast, strong medicinal notes, cake malts, dry apples.  This beer wasnt fun at all.  This is not the only disappointing Midnight Sun beer weve had lately.  It seems that the once wonderful Midnight Sun brewery may not be quite so wonderful anymore since the departure of their head-brewer in late 2010.  Or maybe it is just a bad coincidence.  But the least I can do is warn people of a possible decline of the brewery quality.  And as with everything else in my life, the least I can do is usually exactly what I end-up doing.

Bottle from curly, Panty Peeler label. Pours clear golden amber, thin foamy white head, decent retention; no real lacing to speak of. Nose is red delicious apples, sour cream and peaches/apricots. Flavours of peach yogurt and Viognier grapes, rather mouthcoating in a bizarre creamy way. Fascinating stuff, reminds me very strongly of Condrieu. Not a classic Tripel in any way, but a fascinating brew...

This poured a semi cloudy yellow color with a white head. Aroma was lots of candy sugar sweetness and some chamomille and spice notes too. Flavor was lgiht fruits, orange peel candy sugar and chamopmille. A great tripel!

Labeled as Panty Peeler.  From Malt and Vine.  Amber-gold color, pours with a thick head, and a good layer of foam left on top for good.  Fresh citrusy aroma with lots of Belgian yeast, banana, and orange peel.  A bit of zesty lemon as well.  The stuff smells pretty good, like what youd expect from a quality Triple.  The flavor shows most of the same components but is a bit odd.  Barnyard and straw notes are added with a good dose of orange peel, coriander, and Belgian yeasty flavors.  Fortunately, theres not a lot of alcoholic tang that sometimes (for me) is the downfall of the style.  In short, its pretty drinkable stuff.  After about half the bomber I figured out this "odd" note is a metallic flavor that creeps in towards the finish.  Nothing crazy but certainly enough to throw it off.  Still, while not something I need to revisit, overall this is a pretty solid beer.

Bomber shared at a tasting. "Panty Peeler" label.

Appearance : Hazy pale amber with no head.

Aroma : Yeast with notes of banana and light notes of tea.

Taste : Fruity with yest and notes of tea. Yeasty finish with some dust and fruits.

Overall : Not very good. Tastes a bit stale.
Very strong but not out of place for a triple.  Very much to style.  medicinal at first.  then some fruit aromas and tastes poke through.  followed by some vanilla to me.

22 oz. bottle, pours hazy golden yellow with a big white head. Aroma of coriander, other spices, yeast, slight citrus and apple. Flavour is dominated by the spices, with secondary flavours of yeast, dry green apple and citrus. Quite good.

Pours opaque orange with some tiny brown sediment. Aroma of banana, clove, orange, bready malt. Taste is not overly sweet or spiced. Pretty good, has all that good Belgian stuff without being overly sweet and boozy like some tend to be.

Bottle. Man, I cant remember the last time I had a good tripel. Pours a deep hazy orange body with solid frothy white head. Aroma is Belgian spices and coriander. Mouthfeel is medium and smooth with notes of coriander dominating.

Bottle with patfannon and jredmond. Pours a hazy amber with lots of head. Lacing is very nice. Nose is a little Slinky. Taste is a spicy orange flavor with a pop for a mouthfeel. Finishes slow giving time to taste.

22 oz bomber labeled Panty Raider f/2010 Secret Santa-Cloudy golden color w/a slight white head & good lacing. Sweet Belgian aroma. Flavors of a classic Tripel, candied sugar, banana, colander, bread dough, yeast, white pepper, & citrus. Very smooth & easy to drink. First beer from these folks, really enjoying it. Thanks Santa!!
Bomber labeled "Panty Peeler."  Hazy golden color, small white head.  Aroma of straw, white pepper.  Taste is lemon pepper, a little bit odd, especially as it warms.

22 oz bottle as "Panty Peeler".  Orange pour, off-white head.  Sweet malts, banana, orange, light spice, hints of stone fruit, caramel, and some floral hops.  Really nice and drinkable, even though I am not a big fan of tripels.  Not overly sweet.
Bottle from Monument. Pours a copper/amber  with an opaque hue. Some thin white head that recedes pretty quickly. Notes of orange and coriander. NIce and dry finish.

Aroma:Belgian yeast, orange, caramel aromas, vanilla, coriander, clove, banana.

Appearance:Tons of white fluffy head. Large bubbles. Caramel-orange in color.

Taste:Lots of mild flavors in this beer. Spices, coriander, orange. Very nice sweetness. Faint nutty aftertaste.

Palate:Medium body, nice carbonation, very creamy, very smooth experience the entire way.

Overall:This is the orange dreamsicle of beers, but on the subtle side. Tons of delicious flavors, well deserving of its name.

Bottle at Funky 6. Pours hazy gold with a dense, off-white head. Pleasant aroma with yeast and banana. Sweet flavor with some bready malts, fruit, yeast, with nice bitterness. Medium to full in body with average carbonation. Finishes sweet, malty and with some nice alcohol warmth. Very good.

650 ml bottle. July 2010 vintage, labeled as Panty Peeler.  Pours a translucent copper color with a medium off-white head that soon recedes to a fine film. The aroma is that of a big Belgian brew with soapy yeast, coriander and white fruits. The flavor is similar to the nose with a big Belgian yeast character, coriander, oranges,  pears, biscuit and bready malts. The palate is full and smooth with prickly-lively carbonation. The finish is short and dry. Overall: Im not really a big fan fan of tripels, but Im always ready to give them another chance, and this one turned out pretty good. Well done Midnight Sun. Paired will with meatloaf and garlic mashed potatoes.

The Dan Journal #395. Tasted 8/21/10. 22oz bomber. Hazy with a golden hue. Moldy off-white head. Aromas of orange zest and bananas. Slightly rustic. Full bodied and very zesty. Bright effervescence and a dry finish. Crisp citrus with a spotlight on the orange. Dark toasty malts and a mildly chalky mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Bottle aka Panty Peeler.  For a tripel, it doesnt get any better looking.  Glowing golden orange pour with a light haze and a finger of creamy sand colored head.  Nose is full of yeast and gives off a dry impression.  Some citrus, ala the orange peel, and traditional Belgian spice.  Smooth and sweet citrus up front before a brisk, spicey bite in the tail.  Has this element that Id compare to orange marmalade before the yeast and spiciness of the tail.  A fun little ride.

On tap at Beer Revolution. Beautiful pour as it shimmers a bright golden orange with a thick, creamy white head. This really looks great in a snifter! The aroma is very nice too, with lots of tropical fruit, apricot, some spicy yeast character (mostly mild spices like coriander). The flavor is very fruity with some noticeable candy sugar and pleasantly spiced with a mild hop finish for the style. I liked the unusual tropical feel to this beer. Would recommend this to anyone who likes tripels.
So strong, so smooth and delicious. light malts, not much head. sweet and well balanced the whole way through. Can barely tell its so strong until its too late.
Big off-white head, cloudy dark-orange pour. Good aroma, hint of tripel. Mmm, smooth and mildly tripel-spicy. Looks good, tastes good, feels good. Winner!

Bottle labeled as Midnight Sun Panty Peeler. Pours with a hazy golden body and a large egg-shell colored head. Aroma of coriander, citrus peel, candi sugar, light coffee (?),  perfume, lavender, wheat, apricot. Taste is dry, lightly buttery, vanilla, metallic, bitter, orange peel, apricot everywhere. Perfumey, stonefruit. Very lively bubbles, bitter. Vanilla everywhere as well.

Bottle. Pours a hazy amber gold with a white head that dissipates completely but slowly. Aroma is complex with citrus and spice being the main notes with some underlying earthy yeast and sweet grains. Flavor is also spice with some slight citrus and earthy yeast.

Bottle: Yellow gold color with a quite "stiff" yeast aroma as well as rubber noted.  Herbal flavors like chamomile tea as well as some citrus notes.  The body is extremely smooth which makes this easy to drink even if you arent a fan of Belgians (i.e., me).  The aftertaste is mild and smooth as well.
Bottle.  Hazy light orange with a thin white head.  Musty fruity aroma won a little plastic or band-aid.   Light Belgian pale malt backbone and some citrusy spice flavors.
A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho. one of the better triples ive had in a long time.

Bomber.

Friggin solid beer. The best American Tripel? Quite possibly. Gorgeous thick full mouthfeel never approaches sticky. Carbonation is quite modest, but for this particular beer it works very well. Orange peel is apparent, just the right level of sweetness with less hop snap than many US tripels.

Bottle thanks to Alex! Panty Peeler label. Pours orange amber with white head. Nose is peel, coriander and wheats. Taste is citrus, golden wheat, orange peel, coriander, light white pepper spices and light bread yeast.

22oz bomber, bottled the second week of March, say the notches.  Bought from Healthy Spirits for like $12-13 or so.  Clear medium orange with a small yellowish white head, fair retention.  Belgian yeast up front with some citrus notes and spicy coriander and peppery notes behind.  Flavor is much doughier and actually almost buttery, though maybe I think Im getting the tiniest bit of leathery brett, so maybe thats the buttery thing thats going on.  Stronger orange notes and stronger coriander than the nose.  Finishes with some alcohol, dry, bitterness at a 3.  High carbonation with a medium body.  Not overly impressed, but not bad at all.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: This beer was glorious.  The witbier spices they used were perfectly measured, adding a level of complexity but not overpowering the beer.  Rich flavor and mouthfeel.  Superb.

Bottle courtesy of sebletitje.  Poured a hazy orange color with a huge egg-shell head.  Nose is fruity with big notes of apple and light citrus also pale malt, honey, caramel and light spice.  Medium body with tingly carbonation.  Flavor is sweet fruit mostly apple, malt, toffee, light wood, and spicy yeast.  Finishes dry.

Panty Peeler label

22 oz bottle poured into a large snifter.

A- Body is a thick, uniformly cloudy straw yellow hue. Pours with a soapy 2-3 finger frothing white head. Head has good retention once in fades to the 1 finger mark. Some small traces of lacing are left down the glass.

S- Floral hops, pale fruits, and phenols mix for the nose. The nose is slightly above average and the components do not blend as they should.

T- Apple and pear come through the most for the initial flavor and have both mild sweet and tart components while the backbone is a substantial spicy, sweet bready yeast flavor. Soft floral and noble hops come through for the finish and balance this brew out with a slight bitter and herbal component...the finish is mostly dry but a slight alcohol heat does come through.

P- a medium amount of soft carbonation and a light to moderate weight body that is very smooth secondary to the bready yeast.

O-This is a wonderful American brewed Belgian Tripel. It really hits all the necessary components of the style. The overall character is soft, smooth, and silky- but never thin or boring. The ABV is well hidden except in the nose. I would love to have this again and really wish this brewery were available in Pittsburgh.
