Bottle.  A hazy golden amber color with a creamy and foamy off-white head.  The orange peel and coriander permeate the aroma with a light lemon and spicy zest.  A Spicy and peppery flavor with a lingering dry citrus finish.

Bottle. Shared with Tarheels who just wrote an essay about this beer so Ill say this: Was is really good? Yes. The best tripel Ive ever tried? Definitely maybe. Will you ever be able to find it? Not if you dont live in the pacific northwest or Alaska. You should still try to find it though.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2010 Bomber courtesy of wavers1. Whoa whoa whoa. This was excellent. Pours a cloudy deep orange with a 2-3 finger white head that has okay retention and lacing. Aroma is just outstanding with butterscotch, tamarind, orange liquor, rum soaked sponge cake. Taste is sweet but dry, spicy, and has almost a saison lightness. As it warms the 8.5% is very apparent and gives this an orange creamsickle richness, full of kahlua, white russian. Just superbly outstanding.

Pours hazy golden with a massive rich off-white head and a fruit and yeast aroma. It more resembles a saison than a tripel, as it is enhanced with orange peel and coriander. Nevertheless, it has a very yeasty character and a delicious caramel malt flavor.
Pours golden with minimal head. Lots of orange peel, yeast, bubblegum and spice in the aroma. Lively carbonation. Citrus peel, coriander, bread and bubblegum taste.

It pores a clear orange color with a thin white head that foams up quick and thins out. But the laser cut circle on the bottom of the glass bubbled up refreshing hop aromas. The nose is full of toasted nuts, orange peel, and vanilla clove. As you sip on this amazing brew you can really taste the orange peel and other spices added. It coats your mouth like a cold toffee and has a nice hop bitterness on the tip of your tongue. Overall it is a great brew with good carbonation and good hop flavor, would definitely peel off my pantys.

Courtesy of sebletitje. Pours gold with off white head. The aroma is full with prunes, apples, apricots, peach, some malt sweetness and a touch of yeasty spice. It smells so fresh and inviting and also begins to pick up coriander and cinnamon. The taste is similar with dark fruitiness from prunes, red apples as well as apricots and peach to go along with some malts sweetness and vague winter spices in the background. It ends smooth, sweet and refreshing. This one hit the spot.

I really enjoyed this bad boy.  Thanks to sebletitje for sharing.  Pours hazy yellow with a white head.  Nose is caramel, apple, orange peel, citrus, and sugar.  The flavor is a mix between a sweet white ale and an abbey tripel.  It has slight yeastyness of the tripel and the citrus and coriander presence of a white ale.  Lots of sweetness and style-mixing.  Very nice beer.  Medium-bodied and a lingering sugar-citrus finish.

On tap at City Beer as Panty Peeler. Smooth tripel aroma. A bit of honey and yeasty bubblegum aroma. Light sweet and headily aromatic. Neutral fruity notes, nice nose for American tripel. Hazy golden amber with thin off-white lacing head. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Starts sweet with honey and caramel malt, mild candi sugar. Very little hops bitterness but good tripel yeasty finish. Light chalky after with muted alcohol warming, a bit watery.
Bottle shared by hellbilly.  Deep gold pour with a foamy head.  Light fruit and yeast in the aroma.  Very dry, no sweetness.  Highly carbonated.  Nice.  Thanks Josh!

non sans culotte - and hence my disappointment.  Maybe pouring another six bottles or so into her might help?  Dark yellow with a fluffy white head.  Aroma of orange, banana, and Belgian yeast with a similar taste and mild spice in the finish.

22oz bottle @Tampa Wkly Gathering @BT Thanks sebletitje-pours a thin white head and gold color.  Aroma is apple/pear, cinnamon, dry, light/medium malt, yeast.  Taste is apple/pear, cinnamon/nutmeg, dry, light/medium malt, yeast.  Nice.

courtesy of googzoid10.
another phenomenal offering by MS.
The best abbey trippel thousands of miles from Belgium? this one is bombastic.
pours golden, white head.
Aroma lots of fruits for a nice sugary aroma, light spices; coriander, Belgian yeast.
Favors, Belgian yeast, fruity; apricot, peach, banana, fresh orange, spices and coriander.Medium carbonation with a earthly yeasty finish, leaning on some faint tartness.
Lots of good sweetness, 8.5% easy to drink, complex.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 Draft, City Beer Store.  This beer poured a hazy orange-ish yellow with a pretty good white head.  The aroma was a bit musty but mostly coriander and orange peel dominant.  Some caramel malt backs the whole thing up.  Not enough depth of earthy Belgian yeast for my tastes.  The flavor was medium sweet but too much for me.  It’s not cloying or unpleasant, but the sweetness makes the beer feel simpler/shallower than it might otherwise.  There’s a fair bit of spice, but it’s a pretty standard mix for the style.  I guess I just had my expectations set a bit high for this brewery.  Happily, I have a number of their bottles to improve my opinion.

Pours a clear golden-orange with a nice white head.
On draft at City Beer during SF beer week.  
Crisp orange aroma. 

Round medium mouthfeel with belgian great yeast present.

Orange and corriander are present in a well-rounded very drinkable beer, although nothing stands out.   Very good.

I want to revisit this one, since I had it at the end of a lot of big beers.  Very yeasty, esthery, and aromatic, with a little juicy peach/banana character to it.  The coriander and orange zest come through well.  Lots of spiciness as I smell and taste it, maybe a touch of dank earthiness.  Richly bready, sweet maltiness underlies it.   Really like the feel, has a moderately full body with a pleasant bubbliness.

Bottle 65cl. @ Chris Os Night of the Gaylords. [ As Midnight Sun Panty Peeler Tripel ]. Unclear medium orange color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, light to moderate hoppy, moderate yeasty, orange - apricot, spicy - coriander notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091229]

22oz bottle thanks to photomike.   Hazy gold color with a medium sized, frothy white head.   The aroma has a crazy yeast fruitiness that almost smells like brett.   Bright, leathery, and grassy.   The flavor is also very fruity with orange, some grass, and a light sweetness.   Medium bodied with medium carbonation.   Has definite brett-like character without really feeling like it has brett.   Interesting and pretty good stuff.

Bottle courtesy bret27 I think. Pours light cloudy gold with a fluffy off-white head. Appley aroma, with almost an apple pie/apple crisp tartness to it. A Brett-like note as well which is probably just the bitter orange peel. Flavors of apples and bananas, very fruity with a touch of spice. Heavy on the palate with soft carbonation. A big bad tripel for sure.

650 ml bottle thanks to Alex. Pours a clear golden color with a large white head. A sweet malty nose, light spices, coriander, sweet fruit. A similar flavor; spicy orange, sweet malty goodness, lots of fruity esters, yeasty and somewhat dry. Well-balanced. Tasty.

Sampled at the SLC tasting 1/23/10 - Thanks Doug for this one! 
Appearance: Poured clear golden with a nice amount of white head 
Aroma: Belgian yeast, candy, sweet fruits, spices
Taste: Fruity, candy, spices, yeast, alcohol 
A decent beer, well balanced.
A Mes rate. Bottle at Chris Os Night of the Gaylords.Hazy gold with a thin white head. Very fruity, slightly sour and not in a good way and lots of sickly malt. Bad beer, even worse name.

Bottle from NickD717, thanks! Golden color, pours a huge head. Orange and coreander in the aroma. Alcoholic, slightly yeasty flavor with coreander. Fruity notes; pear and orange. Medium bodied. Alcohol is dominating.
Bottle at Chriso Gaylord tasting 09.  Thanks again to Ken for the splendours of his trading.  Hazy gold, thin off white head.  Lemony aroma.  Bit pukey in mouth.  Not a good beer.  Pukey malts.

Bottled (As Panty Peeler). Hazy orange colour, not much head. Aroma is herbal, a bit spicy as well as fruity and floral hops. Flavour is quite much the same, ending rather fruity and earthy. Alcohol gives a warming feeling while you drink.

22oz bottle. Pours murky orange with a foamy white head. Very lively carbonation. Aroma is of citrus, hops, yeast, spice, and malt. Taste is of light hops, citrus, spice, and yeast. Nice grassy taste. Strange buttery taste to it as well. Lingering taste of citrus fruit. Very light, heavily carbonated mouthfeel. Had way more fruit to it that I had expected, making it taste very fresh and enjoyable. A solid beer, if nothing else.

22 oz. from Full Throttle Bottles. Transparent copper color. No head to speak of, which is a bit disappointing. Wow, a very nice pungent fruit flavor just wrecks my nostrils i.e. yeast and a bouquet of fruits just hit my nose. There may be a pear and a peach in the aroma, but just a lovely range of fruits. Nice fruit flavor follows that fruit aroma as well. The yeast is completely overshadowed by the fruit, in terms of flavor. Damn, I havent had a fruit flavor Nice thick creamy texture. The fruits are the greatest part of this beer (to me). Overall, I have had some better Tripels, but I have had some better Tripels. I am not disappointed in the least, just wish there was more than a fruit bouquet.

bomber of Panty Peeler thanks to brewboone.  Pours a clear golden color with an off-white head.  Nose is of orange rind and spice.  Taste is of spices, pepper and orange peel.  Mouthfeel is dry and had lots of carbonation.  This was very saison-like, IMO.

Bottle shared by Nick3 on BA.  Thanks, Nick!  Good old Panty Peeler - been looking forward to this one.  Pours hazy golden with a large creamy white head and good lacing.  Great aroma, with yeast, pale malt, light fruits, and spices.  Flavor is slightly sweet pale malt, yeast, earth, citrus/orange, coriander and other spices.  Palate is smooth and medium-bodied with soft yet lively carbonation.  Pretty solid tripel overall.

Bottle. Pours with a much darker color than a usual triple. Pours with a fairly large head with good lacing. Fruity notes of orange and clove, nice flavors of spices and fruit, mainly orange and lemon

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2010 Aroma is highly apple focused. Lightly wheaty, lightly spiced from coriander/ginger. Cloudy orange color with a creamily bodied head. Body is moderately carbonated, taste is effervescent sweetness.

Bottle. Rich amber beer with a cream colored head. Estery (peach) aroma with light yeast and light malt. Fruity ester flavor with malt and yeast. Medium bodied. Sumemr fruits lingers with yeast and light spice.

From bomber courtesy Hannont - mucho gracias!  Pours a marmalade, muddy orange with a robust off white head.  Aroma is light and fruity, yet very enjoyable.....orange, lemon...some bready/yeasty aromas, and a dose of spice...already the name of this beer is becoming more appropriate.  Flavor has a heavy dose of fruit, but is also a bit more yeast-forward...plenty of coriander and other spice working in the background, but it stays light and easy to drink throughout for a Tripel.  Palate is smooth and has an appropriate level of carbonation.  Reminder to self...book a trip to AK one of these days, and ensure Anchorage is on the ticket...yet to be disappointed by MS!

Midnight Sun Panty Peeler on the bottle.

Appearance:  Pours a vibrant amber gold with a nice gathering of white froth at the top.

Aroma:  Cloves, Belgian yeast, flowers, orange, grapefruit and maybe even cranberry.

Taste: Cloves, coriander, bitter Euro hops, funky Tripel Belgian yeast. Finishes spicy and bitter.

Mouthfeel: Very fizzy and medium bodied. Not too syrupy.

Overall:  I like the extra goodness outside of the Tripel yeast. Ive had so many beers in this style that have been similar, this has a nice layer of citrus and berry twang to it.

Bottle and wow what an interesting beer.  Pours a gold/orange pour with a nice little head.  Aroma is loaded with bread, yeast, fruit, spices and some good fruit.  Flavor is much funkier than I expected with some good spice, yeast and light citrus notes.  MMMM MMMM MMMM!

My Bottle from savnac says Panty Peeler, so not sure on the vintage - Pours a hazy orange with a small off white head...aroma is lightly spiced, yeasty, doughy with lemon and orange...creamy in the mouth, the citrus spice works to balance the grainy bready component...the mouthfeel is almost lusious, with fine bubbles cutting thru the gravity of the brew...finish is lightly bitter with a lingering honey sweetness...very tasty...Thanks Ira!
Bomber. Pours clear dark gold with a creamy white head. Lightly spicy sweet aroma, Medium body. Sweet taste of apricot and bread. The orange and coriander finish strong.

Appearance: Pours a bright, orange-gold body with a tall, finely-textured, white head.

Smell: Sweet-smelling, candyish nose of malts peppered with punchy notes of dried coriander and floral, bitterish orange peel.

Taste: Sweet, delicately bready malts stippled with traces honey and treacle. The herbaceous, spicy coriander adds a nice pungent accent. As does the added orange peels which combine with the sweet sugars to give off a taste of chilled marmalade. Additional fruitiness tasting of ripe white peaches. No more than the faintest hop bitterness at the halfway mark. Final touches of citrus and spice in the drying finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. Some sugary stickiness to the luscious mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Recommended. Though a little on the sweet side, it was still quite enjoyable. A pleasant tripel from Midnight Sun.

Pours a somewhat cloudy gold into the glass with a white head.  Aroma is spicy with notes of apricot and orange.  Flavor is wonderfully akin to the aroma.  The body is soft and carbonated.  Really an incredible brew.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of fruit, Belgian yeast, coriander, light white pepper, curacao, light spices, slight hops, slight tropical fruit, slight pear, slight peach, and some citrus.  Poured orange/amber in color with a medium-sized, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of Belgian yeast, fruit, fruit nectar, curacao, hops, slight caramel, light coriander, light pepper, and pear.  Medium body.  Average to lively carbonation.  Sweet, Belgian yeast, fruit, hops, and pear finish is dry.  8.5%ABV is totally hidden.

bottle with no date notched on it from psprings...

hazy golden color with a super soft soapy white head. 

the nose has an odd smokiness to it along with a savory yeast note, orange, peaches, pale malty sweetness, wood and a fruity sourness. 

the flavor is much the same... peaches, oranges, yeast and a spicy finish. it is warming (mentally and physically) and drying from abv% and spice.

the medium body feels sharp in the mouth yet has airy carbonation. 7/3/7/3/15/3.5

Bottle sample.  Slighty hazy tan pour, plenty of carbonation with an almost weird overly sweet aroma.  Although the aroma didnt do much for me, the flavor did!  Flavor was plenty of malt, smooth sugar sweetness, spice and finished very smooth/well balanced.

"Perfectly heady experience.  Ride free."
6/18/2009:  The aroma of Midnight Sun Panty Peeler Belgian-Style Tripel is laden with heavy malt, orange citurs, hints of smoke and some really strange deli meat characteristic.  The flavor is also quite malty (chewy wheat) and moderately sweet.  It also has dried orange/grapefruit/apricot flavors that are reserved.  There is a hint of alcohol in the nose and a soft spiciness in the finish.  This beer has a deep marigold color and is cloudy with a foamy beige head that falls and remains a frothy crown.  In addition, the its body is medium-full and the beer has an average mouthfeel.  Overall this is not my taste for this style of beer! 
22 Fl. Oz. bottle (8.5% Alcohol by Volume - 15 IBUs; Month & Week Bottled: FEB 4) from Safeway in Seward, Alaska.  Rating #255 for this beer.

Bottle generously opened at hellbillys 5th of July tasting.  Pours golden in color with a sugary white head of foam.  A tripel in appearance only, it seems.  Much closer to a golden.  Smells and tastes mildly of banana, pear, and caramel against a backdrop of cough syrup - which Im starting to find in anything from Midnight Sun.

22 ounce Panty Peeler bottle shared by cdumler. Thanks! Pours a murky orange color with lots of floaties, though I got the last of the bottle. Medium head with good head retention and lacing. Aroma is bready and spicy with big citrus notes and a bit of a sharp, spicy herbal note, candi sugar and cotton candy. Taste is bready, citrus, lots of spice and herbal notes, candi sugar, cotton candy, toffee. Tart dry fruity finish, getting mightily close to a mild funkiness. Medium bodied.

Bottle with the "Panty Peeler" label .. much darker than anticipated ... copper.  Nice aroma of yeast and herbs.  Silky and buttery, this drinks with a sharp mouthfeel ... and delivers the advertised character in BIG ways ... esthers, fruit, herb.  Nice.  (#3561, 6/23/2009)

Bomber poured a clear golden yellow with a small lasting ivory head. Aromas of coriander, orange peel, pear, light yeast and light spice. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of pear, coriander, orange peel, spice and light yeast with a smooth lingering spiced finish.

22 oz bottle purchased at Bottleworks in Seattle, Washington.  This was labeled as Midnight Sun Panty Peeler.  Pour is hazed golden, slightly dark golden.  Very active carbonation builds up a smallish white head.  Aroma of Belgian yeastiness, sharply sweet maltiness, orange peel citrus and a fair amount of additional "spiciness".  I picked up coriander, and some Champagne type element.  The taste follows the nose quite closely.  The yeast, sweet malt, orange citrus and spice all have their turn, and are nicely balanced.  Palate is above average carbonation, that goes along with the Champagne type taste quite nicely.  Medium body, brief finish.  All in all a different, and tasty Trippel.
Bottle. Pours a bubbling golden orange with a small white head. Belgium yeast, soap, coriander, and bubble gum aromas and flavors. Bad alcohol burn at times. Not a big fan.

Panty Peeler poured Golden orange with  a big fluffy white head. Citrusy nose. Strong orange peel and coriander flavors. Medium body. A good brew if your into orange curacao flavored beer. Not my favorite from MSBC, but its a good brew for the fruit beer people, who dig oranges.

had as panty peeler.

pours a cloudy orange with a medium size egg-shell head, and great lacing.

smell is of yeast, straw, fruit, and some spice.

taste is creamy, fruit, spice, and yeast, end is a little dry.
I like the name Panty Peeler over Epluche-Culotte.  Pours cloudy orange with a thick bubbly white head.  Aroma of citrus, Belgian yeast, and some coriander.  Really refreshing flavor.  Solid brew.

Bottle from Bottle Trek via an internet order. Poured a cloudy orange color with a large white head. I was very impressed with this brew. Loved the blending of hops and malts. Citrus fruit with a little bit of holiday spice made this brew awesome.

What a name. =) Pours a hazy bronze color with a surprsingly small, white head. Aroma is sweet - lots of dried fruit, including apricots, mangoes and golden raisins. While the aroma and the look of this brew werent quite in line with what I think of for a tripel, the flavor is far closer. Lively, bright, full-bodied but with a light mouthfeel. Citrus fruits and mild spices, with a slightly bready counter. Its delicious - another great effort by midnight sun (a brewery I like more with everything I try from them).

Bottle from The Beer Authority, pours a murky orange color with a large, white foamy head.  Aroma of orange peel.  Flavor was full of orange and spice.  Silky mouth feel with a lingering finish.  Excellent take on the style even if my wifes briefs stayed on.

22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market - Olympia, WA
Aroma: Belgian aroma was thick and fruity.  Nice malt backing. 
Appearance: Golden/Orange in color, hazy with a thin head.  
Flavor: Nice Belgian flavor, fruity, dry with a strong Orange peel and coriander flavors added.  
Palate: Dry Belgian finish, with a Good Mouthfeel.  
Overall: A very nice easy drink Belgian ale.

Compliments of Me, shared with a nefarious crew beguiled cut throats.  Label says "Panty Peeler"!  Pours with an orange-gold body topped by a thick, white head with a good amount of lacing. The aroma is slightly sweet with lots of orange notes and some yeasty notes.  Flavour was m both malty and sugary Very ester y with hints of bubblegum. Sweet accents with lots of residual sugar remaining. Decent hop balance and a noticeable alcohol presence.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Compliments of our own Barney Fife Celticbrew, the Sheriff Drbayern, our Own goober and floys the uncles Steve and Tom, Our Earnest T bass Beer Pimp Brian, and our Little Opie Dancin Paul!  ( Guess that makes me Otis!)  Poured a dark yellow that wasa somewhat cloudy.  The head was white, and it had a nice clean aroma, like snow.  The taste was clear and clean with a mild hoppy floral tone.  The mouthfeel was great.  Like to try sharing a bottle with Sarah Palin to see if it works!
Seductive hazy gold, sticky white head, nice aromas of dusty oak, white grapes, and mandarin orange.  More juicy sweetness, not much coriander but a persistent smooth foggy yeast character.

22oz bottle. Aroma of yeast, dried fruit, and spice. Golden/orange with an off white head that leaves a small amount of lace. Sweet and sour with a nice twang. This beer is nicely balanced and masks the alcohol well. Medium bodied with a soft mouth feel and soft carbonation. Overall a very good beer.

[1945-20090116] 22floz bottle. Sweet fruit aroma has lots of orange peel and mild cherry. Slightly hazy, light orange body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head. Heavy orange peel flavour has sweet candied yeast. Medium-full body. Tasty.
(w/ blankboy, garthicus, GregClow, jerc; Labelled "Panty Peeler")

Mine was called Panty Peeler. Poured a very clear orange to amber with a robust white head and very nice lacing rings. Good looking beer.  Nose is of ripe fruit and coriander.  Medium but smooth mouthfeel. Favor is robust with lots of citrus, spices, and some yeast. Good long bitter finish. This is excellent.
Bottle shared by Hophead22. Nice sweet fruity aroma, color is a pale gold. Tastes of dried apricots with a mild spice. Nice clean finish, good beer.

Bottle shared by DuffmanSW.  Pours cloudy yellow with a foamy white head.  Aroma is sweet and fruity with hints of vegetables, pennies, and a touch of horseblanket.  Flavor has alot of dried apricots and is a bit spicy.  Palate is medium and carbonation is lively.  Finishes clean and dry.
22oz bottle, courtesy of DuffManSw. Light fruity aroma, slightly sweet. Apricot/apple flavor too it, slightly dry, pretty tasty.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle from my friend in Oregon.  Pours out an orange color with a white head on it.  Smell is full or orange and coriander, a little bit of hops, some yeast, very pleasing smell.  Taste is fruity and full of citrus and orange, really easy to drink - the 8.5 is not noticed at all.  Very good tripel, probably because it doesnt really taste like a tripel.  The best of this style that I think I have had.

Bomber.  Poured medium orange with some rising carbonation and a creamy, well-retained cap of white head.  The aroma picked up a blend of pale malts, light fruit, and orange meat with accents of coriander, white pepper, and earth.. sweet beneath and spicy around, with fine balance.  The flavor was primarily fruity at the core with honey and pale malt support.. spicy on the edges with orange zest, coriander, and dirty white pepper.. finished with warmed-up spicage.  Medium-bodied with quite a bit of carbonation on the palate.. not a great transition to the spices, warmth, and light sourness on the edges.. still quite tasty and enjoyable.

Bottled 3/2003. The joyride awaits indeed! Pours a hazy orange with a big fluffy white head that over some five minuets time fell off to a loverly white lace ring around the Leffe chalice it fills. Aroma is musty, earthy, fruity, spice. Flavor is unbelievable for its age, for its age nothing! This triple/white? has aged incredibly well, I am just knocked over by the complexity on offer. Flavor is incredible, Im really shocked to say the least! Crisp, spicy, citrus (orange), caramel, yeast with a long, long spicy bitter finish. I found two bottles and the first bottle was somewhat less then stellar, but this bottle has aged incredibly well. This is the bottle we all hope for when we open a vintage bottle, it just transcends greatness. Yum! YMMV!!!
Bottle. Aroma of fruit and spice. Tastes of fruits, malty caramel and then spice. Black pepper, bitter orange peel and corriander. Quite nice.

Bottle shared at the Smoke from the Oak release, by the illustrious and lovely Naproxen.  Bottled as Panty Peeler. Pours a light hazy gold with a thin white head.  Citrus, coriander, and yeast on the nose.  Medium to thick body with a nice sweetness and a hint of banana.  Finishes lightly and with more banana and yeast.  This was pretty tasty, but did not result in the peeling of any panties, so the label may have been a bit misleading.

22oz bottle.  (Panty Peeler)  Pours a cloudy medium orange amber with a good sized off white head.  very sweet and fruity nose with lots of apricot and peach.  Flavor was good and yeasty, crisp finish.
22oz. bomber, labeled Panty Peeler.  Pours a nice light amber with a white head.  Orange and yeast in the nose.  Flavor is yeasty with bitter orange and spice.  Nice tripel.

Bottle. After almost a year and a half of trying to trade for or buy this beer Im finally able to acquire 3 bottles !!! This review is for the two my wife and I drank last night, labeled as Panty Peeler (accurate name !!). Pours a hazy orange, small wispy off-white head that hangs around the edges. Aroma is sweet notes of orange, banana, spices and yeast. Flavor delivers on what the aroma promised, spices, orange, mango and a touch of yeast. I realize they call this a triple, but with the curacao and coriander, this could easily pass for an Imperial Wit or a Triple Wit (too bad these styles dont exsist !) Really great and enjoyable, too bad Im sending the third bottle out on a trade. Ill need to get some more of this !

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy orange gold with a moderate linen white head that lasted through mid-glass and left virtually no lace.  Pleasant aroma of Belgian yeast along with some malt, orange, and lemon.  The flavor is very enjoyable with Belgian yeast, malt, orange, lemon, coriander, and candi sugar.  Mild bitterness at the finish.  Just a bit slippery on the palate, kind of like a peach or mango, which suits this beer quite well.  The alcohol is well hidden.  Overall. a very good American tripel.

Bottle (22oz) shared with Blankboy, GregClow, jerc & mabel -- courtesy of j&m. 

Color
Slight haze. Orange - yellow.

Carbonation
Medium - quite visible

Aroma
Orange. Lemon rind. Quite perfumy.

Flavor
Quite an orange flavour, coriander. Some mango notes too. Nice.

Finish
Medium mouthfeel.

Bottle from Liquid Solutions as Panty Peeler. Hazy orange gold color with a large white head that does some lacing. Aromas of spice and miniscule funk. Medium body with fine carbonation. Flavor is a little kandi, some citrus zest, and some really nice spice - including perhaps some vanilla. A refreshing tripel compared to many. Finishes towards dry. Really very tasty.

Bottle (22oz) shared with garthicus, GregClow, jerc & mabel -- courtesy of j&m. Labeled Panty Peeler. Pours a hazy yellow-gold with an average size diminishing frothy white head. Aroma of yeast, oranges, candi sugar, honey, herbs (coriander I guess) and spices. Slightly sweet flavour of bubble gum, fruit, yeast, herbs and spices. Some bitterness in the finish. Alcohols well hidden. Medium bodied. Pretty good, nothing great but I like it.

Hazy golden pour with a very small white head and zero lacing. Hefty coriander over a nice malt scent and some orange backdrop. Very orange flavor with a nice coriander burn and the typical yeast flavor. Solid offering and a fantastic label and name of course.

2009-01-16. Lightly hazy golden yellow body with a modest off-white head. (3+) Aroma of sweet pale malt, with spices over top. Coriander? (7+) Flavour is similar with a sweet pale malt base, light spice and coriander. Smooth average to medium palate. Rather pleasant. Bottle labeled Panty Peeler from Brown Jug, Anchorage

Pours light copper with nice white head.  Nose is orange and spice.  Flavor is orange, with bread dough and spice.  It does have that Belgian yeast also in the flavor, and once I get smart, Ill figure out what to call it Very crisp with a nice sweet finish.

22oz bottle. Slowly starting to enjoy this style. Definitely a fan of the brewer... Spicy, phenolic aroma of Belgian yeast, cloves and some citrus zest. Some bread crust and dried tree bark as far as the malt profile goes. Mostly spice and yeast forward nose. Pours a brilliant clear copper with evidence of intense carbonation and a thick white head. Flavor is mostly sweeter malt. Candi sugar. Citrus zest. Slightly rubbery yeast. Bread dough and more tree bark. Only the slightest essence of coriander on the tongue. Mostly candi sugar and yeast. Medium bodied. Snappy carbonation with a distracting oiliness on the tongue. Finishes short and mostly sweet with only the smallest touch of yeast. Thanks Todd!
Bottle in Japan.  Pours a hazy orange golden body with a white creamy head.  Sweet fruity aroma, citrus, pear, and zesty spices pepper like.  Dam fine take on a trippel.  haha funny name too.

Bomber from Hannont, thanks Todd.  Shared with my girlfriends family christmas day 2008.  Pours orange with a 1 finger tan head.  Nose is light and sweet, touch of spice, touch of orange peel and coriander.  Taste is light, spice prickly on the tongue.  A little shallow on the palate and as Im not a big tripel guy this one has too much spice for me, oh well.

2007 bomber, aged about one year.  The cloudy, orange-amber body is topped with a massive, frothy column of off white foam.  Displaying excellent retention, the head slowly settles, but not without leaving dense, sticky, cloud-like patches of foam on the glass.  Aromatics include light candy sugar, lemon chiffon, orange peel, and mild coriander.  There is a creaminess that smooths out some of the candy sugar sweetness, which I appreciate, along with a uniquely Belgian, doughy yeast profile.  Flavors, too, show a formidable candied orange and lemon zest element, which works nicely with the creamy, sugary sweetness and delicate, earthy spicing.  Nutmeg also emerges, lending further woodsy bitterness, while peppery, floral hops show strong on the finish.  Substantially bodied, with fizzy, lively carbonation, the sugary profile gets a bit heavy over time, but is sublime in low doses.  I am not a tripel fan, in general, but this one is right up there with the best that any American brewery I have sampled has to offer.

22 oz bottle.  Clear peachy brown with a fluffy white head.  Nose is yeast, coriander and orange peel with hints of honey and clover.  Crisp with a sharp tang.  Smooths out leaving a light tongue tingle.  Taste is creamy green banana, bitter orange peel and a touch of candi sweetness.  Reminds me of St. B’s; one of my favorite tripels.

This one pours a deep golden orange with a fluffy white three-finger head that recedes to an inch-thick cap that lingers throughout. The lacing is very good.

The aroma is a spiced up version of a typical tripel. It has the generous Belgian yeast aroma and slight candied sugar presence. But on top of that I get a healthy dose of citrus hops, lemons and oranges, and coriander.

The taste starts out with the citrus hops, with a hint of lemony tartness in the background. The Belgian yeast is present as well and the finish has a touch of the lemon zest and a generous dose of spices. I also got an interested toasted grain presence throughout which I wasn’t expecting.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied with lots of carbonation with a slightly dry, toasty finish.

This is another creative take on a Belgian style from Midnight Sun, who I continue to be impressed with in general. Not one of my favorites from them but still recommended.

bottle.  thanks glkaiser.  Panty Peeler is a great name.  copper hazy with thin head.  orange, rich malts, yeast and spice make a well rounded aroma.  strong marmelade jam flavor and sticky syrup texture.  fruit is dominant in this triple.  smooth malting and light spice.  finish is dry  and slightly bitter.

22oz bottle from hannont on 5/8/08/  Pours a cloudy yellow amber color.  Excellent aroma, of a little bit of banana, some corriander.  really nice.  Taste is sweet, easy to drink.  A bit orange zest melds with the sweetness.  Excellent.  Truly one of the best Belgian triples.  A pleasant surprise.  I feel no qualms about rating this much higher than the average.
Draft at brewery, white head, cloudy gold color, strong orange aroma. Well concealed alcohol. A very tasty brew with a orange and spice notes. Very drinkable

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2008 I really enjoyed this, very traditional, and true to style.  A nice tribute to regional Belgian styles, and this brewery has it in spades.  Lots of effervescent lighter fruits in this one, pears, grapes, and a light yeastiness, which mellows into a nice creamy mouthfeel.  Very drinkable, finishing very dry on the palate.
Bottle. Fine aroma. Brown with light head, spicy taste, fine brew. Surprised the label met ATF approval.

22 oz. bottle.  Produces a decent head atop a cloudy orange body.  The orange is clearly noticeable on first aroma.  This beer is surprisingly smooth and mellow considering its ABV.  Not a huge fan of this variety but this stuff is OK.
An old rating i finally got to entering. Aroma was really spicy and dry and a light hoppiness. A real big bubbliness to this.

22oz bottle thanks to Todd for the freebie.....a caveat as this is not one of my favored styles..... poured a crisp semi-transparent golden brown with a thin soapy white head.  looked really nice!..... bananas, sweet tropical and light citrus fruit, and candied sugar in the aroma....not much to say about the flavor as it was consistent with the nose.  a lively carbonated mouthfeel was a little too much for me and the general level of sweetness was a little high.  not bad though for a tripel.

Received a 22-oz bomber from LiquidSolutions.biz and shared with MN group. Pours a semi-hazy golden brew with a thick white head that has some excellent retention and lacing. Aroma of fruity and golden grain malts, some banana esters, cloves, candi sugar and a touch of citrus and barnyard funk. Taste is quite sweet, some extra carbonation with flavors of sweet crystal malts, banana esters, some pear and a touch of cloves. Finish is slightly metallic from the high alcohol but the sweet and yeast flavors slowly disappear after the finish.

Poured a golden lager color with a big active head.  Nose of banana, light citrus, spices, and the metal that reminds me of the trappist tripels.  Flavor much sweeter than I was expecting, sugary fruit and yeast, not very bitter at all.  A slight metallic finish that I didnt find so dry as some others have noted, with a faint hint of alcohol, which I suppose means its well hidden at 9%.  Very enjoyable for a fairly-priced 9% bomber, particularly here in Southeast AK where selection is inevitably limited.

22 oz. bottle - pours clear gold at first with increasing cloudiness as the residue gets slightly stirred up; lots of carbonation and a thin white head; big aromas of yeast, grapes and pears; yeast and slight malt flavors; creamy texture and dry finish
great beer, thanks dave.  Light sweet aroma.  Tastes sweet and fruty, with a bit of an earthy aftertaste.  dry finish cuts out most of that though

Bottle Thanks to JoeMcPhee and his Santa: Hazy golden pour. Has a rich fruity aroma. Lots of apple skin, slight vinous qualities, yeast and honey. Fruity flavor, yet it has a nice dryness to balance. Light honeyish sweetness with crisp apple hints and a peppery dry finish to balance. Pretty nice.

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel" tasting.  Hazy, dirty orange with small dense white head.  Orange, yeasty aroma with alc, oak and dough.  Orange flavor with dough, alc, red fruit, will have to try again, very nice age.  Medium to full body, well carbonated.  Very nice overall as well.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2009 Thanks to Joe and his Santa. This brew had everything in it for me. A bit of sour, funk, and sweet with a hint of hop bitterness. Very mellow alcohol with some yeast and malts. Pretty nice body and overall nice beer.

Thanks to Santa for sending this gem my way.  Pale golden beer, thin white head.  Sweet lightly honeyish malt aroma, some soft clovey spice over a fairly lean Belgian malt base.  Light bubble gum flavour well integrated with the clovey spice and light herbal/earthy hopping.  Tasting pretty good really.  One of the better American tripels Ive had.

Bottle, thanks to JoeMcPhee.  Light orange, yellowish pour.  Aroma is slightly funky, but also sweet from fruit and malt.  Flavor is sweet banana, citrusy, with some earthy malt and bubblegum also.  Pretty tasty beer.

Beautiful copper pour with a off white head   that did not last as long as I would have liked but it settled to a few wimpy foam islands.My nose got Apricots , cream sherry and bakers yeast, First sip I thought of Graind Marinier and barleywine its pretty robust malty and fruity and a little hot on the alcohol,A little under carbonated but the mouthfeel was smooth and the body medium the finish spicy . Definately a sipper but very delicious.

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel".  Thanks to andrew for grabbing this one.  Pours a hazy yellow orange with a beige head.  Aroma of phenols.  Citrus cookie and a bit funky.  Phenol alcohols in the flavor as well.  Caramel, citrus, pears, apples.  Maybe this one just needs to open up more.

sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel". pours slight hazy gold with white head. nose of sweet pear, caramel, flavor are really sweet, pear, white grape. lots of alcohol. not good at all.

22. God, I wish these guys would distribute to Seattle. Pours a crystal clear light golden amber with steadily rising carb streams for days and days. Thick foamy platinum blonde head that falls eventually to a big sloppy ring of foam and some cakey lacing. Big old bubble gum, orange zest, and cake batter nose. Gorgeous. These guys clearly love those big trappists and theyre not going to settle for mere provincial interpretation: theyre dialing it up to Homage and setting the controls for the heart of the sun. God damn it, this is a good beer. 
Bodys on the high side of medium, with plenty of tinglingly fizzy carb. They nail that tripel thing. Ya know, that heavily sweet yet still bracingly crisp paradox that the brothers do so well. Must be the spices. Theyre definitely here--the mid-palate is citrus, dark ground spice, bubble gum, and a bit of wet leaves. Long spicy finish. Wonderful stuff.

NorCal December 07 - I honestly had no idea this was a Midnight Sun beer until the other day, after I had drank it, that I was looking around for information on it. A very fruity beer with notes of apricot, raspberries, and honey. Appearance is a golden/orange color with a nice fluffy two finger thick head. Flavors had a wide array of variability. Notes of light fleshy fruits, white wine, vanilla and honey. If tripels were more like this, I might actually start to like them. A very nice beer.

Poured from a 22 oz. bottle.  Murky, golden orange appearance; spotty, milky foam resting in a thin film.  Tart apple and pancake batter aroma; melted butter, sugar.  The bright fruitiness of banana and pineapple leans into some heated spiciness of coriander and clove; some dank grasses on the back.  Full and ebullient.  Tastes crisp and bold, but quieted and dry.  Bitter, sharp spices form a brittle wall around a doughy and dense Belgian core of full fruits and candied floral tones; lavender, orange peel, and pear juice with a very crunchy and wet rosy tone toward the end.  Light to medium bodied, with no show of alcohol; juicy and smooth in the mouth.  Bitter and drying chamomile and further floral tones in the finish.  Fantastic.  Thanks for sharing, Ryan!

22oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a bright, hazy yellow-orange color; huge, textured off-white head with excellent retention and lacing.  Pleasant aroma showing orange peel and bread and a very interesting yeast character; some white pepper and spice.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: very earthy, spicy yeastiness upfront with a good amount of Belgian sugar and dough; a light bit of orange peel and spice come in as well; above-average carbonation, but not sharp; some mildly acidic citrus hops surround a dense, generous tripel.  Good showing of spicy white pepper and citrus throughout.  Lengthy, doughy and yeast finish, with some orange peel.

Bottle from awaisanen . Hazy pale body with a large white head - lasting cover, some lace. The nose is moderately sweet, cotton candy, light spice, golden fruits, cobwebs and herbal hops. Quite nice. The flavor is lightly sweet, lightly bitter with spicy herbal hops, light cotton candy, tangerine, peaches, apples, golden raisins, coriander and light pepper. Medium body is airy with sparkling carbonation and a pithy finish.

22 oz. bottle cellared since 2003. Clear honey orange hue with a white head. Spicy sweet honey and blackpepper smell. Medium bodied with a lively, bubbly yet rich mouthfeel. Taste is a rich honey butter,bready yeasty flavor. Finishes with a nice hop/alcohol tang. 
A year plus time in the cellar has greatly improved the overall character of this brew. Excellent. Feb 2004

text: Mmmm. Very nice. Strong smell of orange/banana. Very light yet flavorful taste. Very much like a Belgian tripel. Bit tart, bit spicy. A very good beer.

Bottle. Thanks to Markus (bu11zeye). Pours a hazy orange color with a msall off-white head. Spicy malty aroma with some yeasty fruity hints. Sweet malty spicy warming flavor with some weak hints of coriander. Spicy alcoholic finish.

Pours a near transparent orange amber with an extremely slow descension of a mi-sized white head. Very pretty and appetizing appearance. The aroma is very sweet, with a tightly wound up fruit profile that accentuates both curacao and coriander spicing. Yeast seems well-utilized. The belgian authenticity is spot-on. Nothing wild, no overly sweet maize or candi sugar that sometimes leaves me resnting the style. alcohol is modest. The flavor unveils additions of honey and toasty grain. Sweetness is medium-high and soft. Bitterness is mild, astringency is soft and adequate. The finish is lightly tart and lingering with sweet malts. Soft and medium bodied palate, mild carbonation. A delicious example of a tough style.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a nice white head.  Aroma is sweet and sour with some yeast/banana aromas.  In the mouth, it starts with a hint of sweet honey, which fades quickly to dry layered with a hint of sour.  As it warms, more fruity sweetness comes out, with hints of apple.

Courtesy boboski.  Cloudy dark straw color with a thin white head.  Sweet aroma without getting too sickly.  A bit perfumy, more so than most tripels.  Medium-bodied, lightly carbonated.  Traditional tripel taste, sweet, some spice on the end.  Decent.
Thanks Bobo!  Poured a hazy and warm orange.  No head at all.  Aroma is sweet orange, with a touch of spice thrown in.  Flavor is a touchy yeasty and slightly sweet.
Bottle from Footbalm, thanks!  Aroma is mostly yeast, dough, and some light spices.  Medium head sits atop a golden body.  The flavor is very yeasty, with definite hints of coriander.  Not bad.
C-Bus 9 shared by moejuck: Bottle: Pours a hazy gold with a white head. Aroma, yeasty, light fruits, some bready notes. Flavor, bready, yeasty, some spices and pale malts.

Epluche-culotte pours a deep golden with tiny floating particles you really have to look to notice which creates a slightly hazy appearence. This beer has a really uniue aroma for a tripel, one I wasnt at all expecting but is very welcomed. The aroma is loaded with a berry sweetness. Strawberry, raspberry, blueberry, and (last but most noticeable) blackberry. A mild spicy dose of alcohol compliments the berry medley. Very interesting aroma and something Im very fond of.

Flavor goes hand in hand with the aroma. Berry flavors abound. Blackberry kicks things off along with some mildly sweet raspberries. Strawberries come along on the finish with an appropriate pale/biscuity maltiness thats hardly noticeable but keeps things from being too fruity. 

Medium bodied with a slightly syrupy mouthfeel. Glides through very smoothly with a pleasant warmth on the swallow from the alcohol. 

I could drink this beer all night until I couldnt drink anymore. With all the berry flavors present I would think it would start to get too sweet but this beer hits the mark just before it turns too sugary.

A great tripel from Midnight Sun. Not at all what I was expecting from a tripel. The fruitiness is there but in a much different form from the fruitiness Im used to seeing in other tripels. Great example!

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a lazing light orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of straw and hops. The flavor has notes of straw, spices, and dusty hops on a powerful sweet malty background.

22oz bomber:  This one pours with a HUGE off white head.  It does linger for awhile.  The color is very hazy orange-tinged dark golden hue.  This one has a very nice aroma. A very nice rendition of the style.

22 oz bottle from Bottletrek.com featured beer selection.  Pours a hazy yellow with a hint of orange.  Huge billowing head with nice lacing.  Sweet aroma of mild spice, orange, and yeast.  Flavor was similiar, but a bit more sweet than your typical Belgian Trippel, but it worked for me.  Creamy mouthfeel with a dry finish with some bitterness.  I really enjoyed this one.
Bottle drunk on 5/5. Hazy apricot color. Frothy, creamy white head. Smells like a perfect triple. Yeasty, smooth and candy sweet. Spicy. Beautiful rendition of the style. Creamy aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden colour. Sweet, fruity, malty, bit sour and wheaty aroma. The flavour is fruity, caramellic, has a good maltiness, some yeast, spices and has a nice dry, bitter-sweetish finish.
Hazy orange colour with a white head. Malty, sweet aroma with fruity and floral notes. Malty, fruity sweet flavor with spicy notes. Light dry and spicy finish.

(Bottle 65 cl) Courtesy of Degarth. Pours a hazy, golden with a tall, dense and lasting, off-white head. Aroma of fruit - banana in particular - and yeast. Medium body with fruity and yeasty flavours. The finish is distinctly bitter. Not the worlds most refined Tripel. 230407

Bottle. Huge fizzy white head that mostly lasted. Good lacing. Clear yellow colour. Good mix of yeast, spice, coriander, clove, citrus, pepper, caramel. Medium to full bodied with an average carbonation and a light alcoholic texture. Flavour was moderated sweet malt with light acidic. Finish was sweet with again a hint of acidic.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a big white head. Malty, spicy, fruity aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.

Bomber. Dated second week of June 06. Beer gushes out of the bottle. Yeast coating in neck. For all of the mess, the beer itself is just a touch murky. Light golden brown with a large, white, frothy, diminishing head.

Before the head diminishes, the aroma is heavily tainted with the smell of dirty metal. Once that fades (mercifully) things clean out and open up. Becomes malty with moderate notes of toasted bread, toasted grain, caramel, cookie; Hoppy with moderate notes of lemon, herb, light note of pine; Yeasty with a light note of basement, a trace of dough; Light notes of coriander and spicy alcohol.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic with a long, warm, lightly bitter, lightly-to-mofderately sweet finish. Hoping it would be bolder.

Lovely mouth feel. The body is full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively.

22oz from Liquid Solutions. A nice copper pour, with a big frothy head. What really leaps out is the huge aroma, with orange peel, a tad of cinnamon, and caramel coming out immediately. As the beer warms and you get the feel of the taste, different characters emerge - a faint hint of spice, a big buttery presence, and more fruit (even an occasional hint of apple). This is a bit too sweet and syrupy to get the highest of marks, but its a superb American tripel.

Bottle: Caramel colored, large spritzy off-white head, dies extremely quickly, sparce lacing. &nbsp For prior pours the head was 

quite nice, but this last pour seemed to die all of a sudden. &nbsp Soft floral nose, rich breadiness, pale fruit as well. &nbsp Sweet 

bready start, soft floral and fruity aspects. &nbsp Very slight alcohol, but well mannered given its 9% ABV. &nbsp Body is quite nice, 

mouthfeel is full to moderate. &nbsp Comes across as a quasi Belgian-American Triple, and it works rather well. &nbsp Floral being Belgian, 

bready being American. &nbsp Warming finish, slight caramel/toffee lingers. &nbsp More amazing stuff from Anchorage!

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2008 Wow...I was expected a lot more from this beer. First, it is way too carbonated. I coundt keep it in the glass. Then, it smells just like a Euro Hefe. The flavor is much too sweet, and way to estery. From my way to limited experience with Belgian beer, they are known for their sublty and complexity. This is like getting hit over the head with tutti-fruity Kool-Aid. Im sorry kids, but Im rating to style here. And if you say Belgian Trippel, you better bring your A game. (And actually, I think that this is a witbier).

Re-rate on 1 June 2008. I must have had a bad batch before. My second experience was much more a tripel, with a decent balance of esters, malt and hops with a dry finish. Pretty good. Re-rated to the middle.

From a 22oz Bottle, 2003 Vintage.  Pours a slightly hazy orangey amber color with a tall layer of soapy white head.  Fruity aromas of pineapple and apricots blend nicely with a twist of bourbony lime.  Definitely a healthy addition of orange peel and coriander, which is quite prominent in the nose.  Medium bodied, prickling carbonated mouthfeel.  Lots of spice.  Flavors of plantain flesh, nutmeg, orange skins, and a touch of coconut husk.  Sweet, but the spicy characters and full carbonation keep it from becoming overbearingly heavy or cloying.  A bit of a nutty character comes out on the backend, along with some more yeasty spice.
Nice deep golden color, spicy aroma and flavor.  A little hoppy for a tripel, has a little thinness that isnt quite right, but overall its a nice rendition of a Belgian tripel.

I havent seen this in stores in a long time, so I was quite suprised to see it available again, although by taste I think this may be older bottles that were just found. Slight oxidation shows, though the character of this beer was strong enough to begin with to cover it up. Very strong spiced nose with corriander, clove, and citrus. Starts sweet with a faint oxidized note, earthy and meaty flavor, and juicy fruity finish. Finish tastes like orange candy with a nice blend of spiciness to keep you wanting more. The carbonation held up great over time and this beer still tastes very nice.

Bottle.  Pours hazy yellow-ish orange with an absolutely huge and rocky off-white creamy head, excellent lacing, completely lasting.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, cookie), average hops (herbs, grass, citrus), average yeast (dough, earth) with notes of alcohol, grape, apple and pear.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, harsh acidity, heavy bitterness, salty; nice flavor, fresh, spicy and herbal.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation and astringent finish.
Bottle.  Murky, burnt yellow color with a white head.  Warm cinnamon and phenols.  Sweet and spicy.  Very strong phenols dominate the flavor.  Everyone kept their panties on.

22 oz bottle, via BA timmcd64.  Pours a slightly hazy dark gold colored body under a two finger fizzy white head.  Aroma is sweet and fruity with some alcohol, apple, banana, yeast, peach, white grapes, and heavy syrupy malt.  Flavor is intensly fruity and malty up front fading to an alcoholic hot finish.  Very light yeast notes.  Mouthfeel is full bodied and thick with an almost syrupy texture.  Carbonation is fizzy and active.  This was OK, but they could tone down the alcohol a little and let the complexities of the malt-yeast relationship express itself more.

A great small-batched trippel!  I belive this one can hold its own against the Trippel Karmilet when its taste-to-price ratio is considered. Im glad to have found this brew..Its truly a magical blend!

Bottled March 2003.  Pours deep amber into a tulip.  Significant fluffy off-white head leaves lacing as it recedes.  Lemon joy notes. Bubbly and fizzy.  Upfront sweet caramel with a lasting alcohol burn.  Lemon joy notes last throughout, but do not come through in the taste. Not a tripel.  btw, I dont use detergent on my glasses...

Pour starts out clear orange but darkens to a dirty brown- orange as the yeast is added to the glass. Lasting moderate dark foam. Aroma of orange, lemon zest and yeast. Heavy palate and a finish like seven grain bread. Strong candy sugar start and middle without being overly sweet and which then melds into the bread flavour. Near room temperature a strong saltiness emerges. Not groovy! Nice for a sipper but too high in alcohol for summer on the patio.

22 oz bottle into a 2oz Snifter glass.  Pours a light golden yellow with a thin white head that is a tiny bit foamy.  Aroma consists of fruity notes mainly touching on the apples.  Flavor is absolutely beautiful tasting of a light sweetness, apples, cantaloupe, honey, and a tiny bit of hops moving into the finish.  Very even, very balanced.  Also has a medium wheaty and yeasty note through the main portion of the body and palate.  A wonderful tripel style from an amazing brewry!

Bottled 2nd week of December (04?). This was really hard to rate, because I dont think it is close to much anything within style. However, I found it to be fairly creative and interesting. Poured with a reddish amber-orange color and very nice and well-sustaining creamy white head. Carbonation bubbles steadily rose to the top of the glass. The aroma stunned me with apples, cherries, and grapes coming through (Is this really a tripel?). The flavor had many of the same elements in the background, but was different. Pineapples were pretty strong with vanilla and honey also in the flavor (some pina-colada type tastes). Not overly sweet like some tripels, and the hop finish was there, but not pronounced. The wheat base was rather hidden. Very interesting and enjoyable, but not the poster child for the style.

This is decent, has a very nice honey sweet malt profile, kind of like honey grahams, with some tart fruitiness, kind of apple like, with some pears, and a bit of citrus acidity rounding it out.  Some yeasty spiciness on the tail end, and finishes up some what bittersweet, almost sour.  Not bad

22oz. bomber thanks to Joeec5. Hazy amber color with a good sized white head. Aroma of caramel, granny smith apples and straw. Sweeter than I normally like a Tripel, but very tasty. A bit of green apple tartness helps cut the sweetness. Some caramel malt and citrus in there as well.

Clear gold color. White head.
Fruity toasty aroma.
Spicy, sweet with a tart finish.

Yellowish with a near green shine; good white fluffy head. Perfumed, Belgian Wyeast N° ZYX nose, spicey, citrus. Phenolic taste, sweet-citrussy, spiced. Burning MF, slick, medium bodied. Im starting to find these over-heated pseudo-Belgians revolting. A cultbeer based on a label and a funny name?

Bottled.  Muddy orange colour, very brief head. Estery pineapple aroma. Sweet and fruity with some citric acidity and strong lemonady orangey notes. Slight almondy yeast character.Too sweet for me to fully appreciate.

Orange hazy colour. Yeasty and orangey aroma. Dry flavour of oranges and minerals with sweet undertones of apricot. Sweeter finish of marmelade and brown sugar.
Poured an amberish color wih a foamying off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, something else that I cant read from my notes, apples, and yeasty.  Flavor is malty and sweet but with some tart apples.

GABF 05.  Pours a light gold with a thin white head.  Lots of banana and clove in the aroma with some pepper and other yeasty notes.  Complex flavor of yeast, phenolics, esters, light pils malt and a light earthy hop bitterness.  Surprisingly clean overall, and finishes a bit sweet.

Somewhat sweet caramel aroma, along with some fermantation. Medium to dark caramel colored body with good head. Caramel flavor with some slight sournessand had an alcohol warming effect. Caramel aftertaste left on palate.

Bottle poured a dark caramel with a big foamy head.
Sour, yeasty, fruity, caramel aroma.

Nice light sweet finish.
Bottled 2005. Yet another hometown fav. Spicy, fruity,  highly effervescent hazy amber beauty.  Ive been told this beer ages very gracefully...upwards of two years.

Cloudy light orange pour with descent head that seems to stick around for some time.  Aroma sees some light frutis, honey, some malts, hops, and a spice that seems to stick throughout the bottle.  Flavor adds a nice alcohol kick with a hint of pepper.  Interesting to say the least.
GABF 05- Pours a clear golden color, small white head. Aroma is banana clove, bubblegum, very yeasty. Flavor is banana, lemons, almost soda like mouthfeel, candy as well.

09.30.05  GABF  Dirty amber pour.  Full of rotty fruits, banana, curacao, clove.  Lighter notes of bubblegum, teaberry.  Spicy to finish with lots of belgie yeasts.  Not usually my favorite type of tripel, but this one works thanks to an irresistible though distant hint of brett.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2005 Bottled second Week of December, Sampled October 2005
This beer is highly carbonated, it shows no respect and after pouring with a four finger thick, tan head promptly oozes over the top of my glass.  The beer is a hazy orangish light amber color.  The aroma is sharp, spicy and herbal, when I go in for a deeper smell, I get notes of higher alcohols, and what seems like a bit of Brett; lightly musty, horse blanket, and even some barnyard character.  The head on this just won’t quite, I think this might be infected, though if it is it might work with this style of beer.

The taste is spritzy and quite sweet up front with notes of orange peel.  The finish is funky with a cotton mouth quality to it, notes of dandelion, ginger, hint of cardamom, some clove, lemons, ripe cheese, and a musty slightly moldy note.  This beer is quite interesting, I am pretty sure that the Brett character was not intended by the brewer, but, as in the case of Fantome, it works here.  The funky note is in the background, and adds to the complexity of the beer.  Though this is starting to be a pattern with the beers I have had from here recently.

Big floral, spicy, light malt aroma. Poured with an overflowing head though boring amber color.
